bestBHT.bht: Above Jesus on the cross was a written charge, a superscription that stated, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This title appeared in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek, following the customary practice of declaring the accusation, name, and residence of the condemned criminal. Luke mentions this title later than the other Evangelists, possibly highlighting the soldiers' sneering mockery and Pilate's role in writing it. Matthew, Mark, and John also include parallel passages that emphasize the significance of this superscription.

The sneer of the soldiers suggested the mention of Pilate’s mockery in writing this superscription.
Pilate’s mockery in writing this superscription.
Archibald T. Robertson: This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews.
The charge written at the top on the cross giving, as was the custom, the accusation on which the criminal was condemned, with his name and residence.
This full title appeared in Latin for law, in Aramaic for the Jews, in Greek for everybody.
John Gill: And a superscription also was written,.... Containing the crime he was charged with, and accused of;

bhtAttempts.bht: The Gospel of Luke records that above Jesus on the cross was a superscription that said, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This written charge displayed in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek was typical of the custom to declare the accusation on which the criminal was condemned, along with their name and residence. It is interesting to note that Luke mentions this title later than the other Evangelists, perhaps emphasizing the sneering mockery of the soldiers and Pilate's role in writing this superscription. The parallel passages in Matthew, Mark, and John highlight the significance of this superscription as well.

Above Jesus on the cross was a written charge, a superscription that stated, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This title appeared in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek, following the customary practice of declaring the accusation, name, and residence of the condemned criminal. Luke mentions this title later than the other Evangelists, possibly highlighting the soldiers' sneering mockery and Pilate's role in writing it. Matthew, Mark, and John also include parallel passages that emphasize the significance of this superscription.

Above Jesus on the cross, a written charge known as a superscription was displayed. It read, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. The inscription included the accusation, the criminal's name, and dwelling place, written in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek. Luke mentions this title later than the other Gospel writers, perhaps to emphasize the soldiers' mockery and Pilate's role in writing it. The parallel passages in Matthew, Mark, and John also highlight the significance of this superscription.

On the cross, Jesus had a superscription written above him, which declared, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. The inscription included the accusation, the criminal's name, and place of residence, displayed in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek. Luke mentions this title later than the other Gospel writers, possibly to highlight the soldiers' mockery and Pilate's involvement in writing it. Additionally, the parallel passages in Matthew, Mark, and John underscore the significance of this superscription.

Above Jesus on the cross, a superscription was written that proclaimed, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This inscription, in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek, followed the custom of stating the accusation, along with the criminal's name and residence. Luke mentions this title later than the other Evangelists, perhaps emphasizing the soldiers' mocking tone and Pilate's involvement in writing this inscription. The parallel passages in Matthew, Mark, and John also highlight the significance of this superscription.
